article:
'Analog photography' is a commonly used term for photography that uses a
progressively changing recording medium, which may be either chemical process
based (e.g., photographic film or plate) or electronic (e.g., vidicon or CCD
sensor). Through common use this term has come to mean anything that is "not
digital" despite some amount of controversy that the use of film isn't a true
"analog" process. http://photo-utopia.blogspot.com/2007/10/chumps-and-
clumps.html http://photo-utopia.blogspot.com/2007/10/chumps-and-
clumps.html

In a film camera that uses the gelatin-silver process, light falling upon
photographic emulsions containing silver halides is recorded as a latent image.
The latent image is subjected to photographic processing, which makes it visible
and insensitive to light.

In a video camera or digital still camera, the signal is captured with a video
camera tube or charge coupled device sensor, which sends the picture to be
processed by the camera's electronics. The signal can be transmitted or recorded
on a storage device for later playback.
